Johnson who recovers very slowly from his last paralytic shock—confined to the sopha in his bed-chamber—his speech almost unintelligible—his countenance cadaverous, and his spirits drooping in despondency. Richard D. Cutts and his sister Mary took tea with us, and I had a long evening visit from Mr Kerr, one of the Senators from the State of Maryland, and one of those whom I am accustomed to respect as among the best and worthiest of men— He is in politics a whig—with principles as pure as in a land of Slavery can be held: and of unsullied honour. We had much conversation on the aspect of our public affairs, with a great preponderance of discouragement.
30. V. Monday.

Gideon Morris is one of the western pioneers who told me he had a Cherokee family, and has some interest in a bill now before the house for carrying into effect a Treaty with the Cherokees— He came to ask my influence to get it through, and referred me to Joseph L. Williams of Tennessee, for information concerning it— Williams spoke to me about it; but the confusion in the house was so great, and I was so much absorbed in the business before it, that I knew just as much of the Cherokee Treaty and Gideon Morris’s claim after he finished as before he began. I must wait till the bill comes up— Mr George Brown came with two gentlemen from Lowell named Bixby, and whom he introduced to me, and with whom I was talkative— At the house, this was the day to call the States for Resolutions, and I had prepared two—calling on the President for information respecting the exploit of Commodore Thomas ap Catesby Jones, at Monterey in California—but Wise and Cushing immediately moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up their exchequer bill— The house taking no heed to my remonstrance, went floundering into Committee Hopkins in the chair. Wise moved to postpone the army appropriation bill, and take up his beloved exchequer— But Filmore insisted upon taking up the army appropriation bill, and the Committee refused to postpone it by a vote of 71 to 82— Reynolds of Illinois moved an amendment of 20000 dollars, for a military survey from the council bluffs to the mouth of Columbia river.— After some discussion in which Cushing avowed his ravenous appetite for the occupation of the Oregon Reynolds’s motion was rejected, and Fillmore seeing that debate would waste time, moved that the Committee should rise for the sole purpose of voting that debate should cease and the bill be reported to the house this day at 3 O’Clock which he afterwards consented to extend to half past 3—all this was done as Fillmore proposed— In the interval while the house was resumed I offered my two resolutions—but Gilmer objected to one, and Mallory to the other and they were not received— There was a snarling debate on the appropriations for West Point Academy; many proposed amendments rejected, and some trifles adopted— The Bill was at last reported to the house, and driven by the screws of the previous question to vote that the question should be taken on its passage now—but then a motion to adjourn was carried in spite of Llandaff W. Andrews’s stare, and yeas and nays— There had been two reports from the Committee of Ways and Means, against the Memorials for W. Cost Johnson’s 200,000,000 of Land stock to pay the State debts— Cushing cram’d the reading of the majority report down the throat of the house, at the cost of many a curse— Franklin Whitney was here this evening.
31. V. Tuesday.

Meeting of the Committee of foreign Affairs. Present Adams, Cushing, Granger, Stuart, Holmes, Caruthers, Meriwether— Absent Everett and Shepherd— I read the Note of the Secretary of State to me, suggesting the wish, that the restrictions on the application of the sum of 40000 dollars proposed to be appropriated for the mission to China, should be struck out from the bill—and after some discussion, I obtained authority 5 to 2 to move in the house to strike out the restrictions. I then requested to be instructed to move in the house, in the name of the Committee the two Resolutions, moved by me in the house yesterday; but objected to by Gilmer and Mallory and not received, calling on the President for information, correspondence, and all the instructions to Commodore Thomas ap Catesby Jones, relating to his invasion of the Californias and capture of Monterey on the 19th. of last October.— Question was made whether the usual exception of what the President might deem it incompatible with the public interest to communicate should not be inserted. I said I had left it out purposely—the act of Commodore Jones being avowedly War, and that being exclusively within the Constitutional power of Congress to declare, I thought the usual exception would be improper. Granger said that on a former occasion he had insisted on the insertion of the usual exception; but as this was a case of actual War the thought the exception should not be inserted— Cushing questioned what he calls the jurisdiction of the Committee—the subject not having been referred to them by the house— But my motion was carried 5 to 2. Holmes and Cushing voting No— Cushing asked and obtained leave to move in the house to take the French claims bill out of the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union next Tuesday.— At the house on the call of the Committees for Reports, James A. Pearce from the Committee on the judiciary presented a report on the General Jackson fine case, which occasioned no small agitation— Pearce moved the printing of 5000 extra copies, and also of C. J. Ingersoll’s minority report of last Summer: but objection was made, and the order to print was only for the usual number— The morning hour expired, and territorial business was the special order of the day.— A bill to authorize the western States to sell their Lands reserved for schools was driven through against the warm remonstrances of Howard of Michigan, and after a heart-rending ovation of the younger Dodge, delegate from Ioway, a bill to pay Ioway Militia for battling against Missouri usurpation, rejected last Summer was now reconsidered and passed.— I delivered at the Clerk’s Office, Franklin Whitney’s petition and papers, and asked their reference to the judiciary Committee—
